markdownRemark.html:
There is a common graph shared amongst front-end developers. It uses Google Trends to compare worldwide Google searches between React (blue) and Angular (red) for the past 4 years. I don't intend on comparing Angular and React. Although the comparison is a hot topic (here and here), they're not quite comparable since they're both in different stages of their lifecycle, along with Angular 2 just now leaving beta.

From Google Trends

The one conclusion I will draw is that after Christmas, it's a long, sleepy weekend for a large amount of developers before the new year. The internet may never sleep, but perhaps there are brief moments when creation slows and the keyboards rest. There is a similar trend with NPM downloads. I don't mean to assume React and Angular make up all the internet, or even a majority. However, I'd like to think of a hardworking developer somewhere in this cold winter that quietly powers down his or her workstation for some time with the family.

I hope we deserve the holiday rest. This has been a wild year. For myself, learning to code this year and falling in love with it has left me anxious and excited for upcoming projects. And in a much broader sense, with the election and recent celebrity deaths, we're ready to begin anew.

In a sense, the holiday break is a goodnight's rest for a career. Perhaps the most noteworthy conclusion to draw from this simple chart is that javascript libraries are becoming more popular. With the new year will come a fresh new day in our careers as developers and more opportunities for new coders to learn additional libraries and novel tools.

frontmatter.title: When Front-end Developers Play: Happy New Year
